termInfo.explanation: A hand where the highest card is an Ace, and there are no pairs or higher hands.
The decisions made during a hand, including bets, raises, calls, and folds.
A playing style characterized by frequently betting and raising rather than calling.
Betting all of a player's remaining chips.
A small forced bet posted by all players before a hand begins, typically in stud games.
A term referring to playing poker continuously, often over long periods.
When a player with a strong hand loses to a player with a much weaker hand, often in a surprising or unlikely way.
The total amount of money a player has set aside for playing poker.
A forced bet placed by the player two seats to the left of the dealer in games like Texas Hold'em and Omaha.
A bet or raise made with a weak hand to deceive other players into folding stronger hands.
The community cards in games like Texas Hold'em and Omaha that all players can use to form their hand.
A hand where the lowest card on the board forms a pair with one of the player's hole cards.
To match the current bet made by another player during a round of betting.
The limit on the number of raises allowed in a betting round.
To pass the action to the next player without making a bet, typically when no bet has been made yet in the current round.
To check initially and then raise after another player bets.
Cards that are dealt face-up in the middle of the table for all players to use to make their hands in games like Texas Hold'em and Omaha.
Cards that are sequentially ranked, such as 7-8 or 10-J.
A bet made by the player who took the lead in the previous round of betting, often on the flop.
The player sitting immediately to the right of the button.
A small disk that marks the dealer position in games with a rotating dealer.
A hand that could potentially improve with one or more specific cards, such as a straight or flush draw.
When a player cannot improve their hand, no matter what card they draw.
A 2 card, which is often the lowest card in many games.
To discard one's cards and forfeit the hand.
The first three community cards dealt in Texas Hold'em and Omaha, placed face-up.
A hand where all five cards are of the same suit.
The probability of forcing an opponent to fold by making a bet or raise.
A community card dealt without any betting action occurring.
A straight draw that requires one specific card to complete, such as needing a 5 in a hand of 7-8-10-J.
When a player decides to stop playing a hand and folds.
The player being referenced in a particular situation, typically the one making the decision.
When no player has any pair or higher, the hand is determined by the highest card in the player's hand.
To receive a card that improves your hand.
The potential future winnings in a hand that might justify calling a bet.
To raise in order to force weaker players to fold, isolating one opponent for a potential heads-up.
A special prize pool that can be won in certain poker games, typically for a specific rare hand.
A hand that has very little value, often a low combination of unconnected cards.
In some poker variants, a card that can serve as a wild card.
A card used to determine the winner of a hand when players have the same rank of cards (e.g., two players have a pair of kings, and the kicker decides the winner).
A hand where the highest card is a King.
To call the big blind instead of raising, often considered a weak move.
A hand that ranks based on the lowest cards, typically in games like Omaha Hi/Lo.
To discard your cards face-down into the discard pile, either after folding or when a hand is over.
A pair made from the middle card of the board.
A hand that is extremely strong, often close to unbeatable, like a full house or higher.
The best possible hand in a given situation.
A betting structure where players can bet all of their chips at any time during the hand.
The highest possible flush, typically made with the Ace as the highest card.
Two cards that are not of the same suit.
A straight draw where you can complete the straight with one of two possible cards (e.g., 5-6-8-9).
A pair in a player's hand that is higher than any card on the board.
A pair of the same card rank dealt as a player's hole cards.
When a player uses all five community cards to make the best hand, usually occurring when no player has a better hand than what the board shows.
The total amount of money bet by all players in a single hand.
The ratio of the current size of the pot to the cost of a contemplated call.
A player's location relative to the dealer, which influences their actions and strategies in the hand.
Four of a kind.
A very fast fold, often used to avoid unnecessary decision-making.
To increase the size of the current bet.
To raise after someone has already raised.
The fifth and final community card dealt in Texas Hold'em and Omaha.
The highest possible hand, consisting of A-K-Q-J-10 of the same suit.
A three of a kind made with a pocket pair and one of the community cards.
The final stage of the hand, where players reveal their cards to determine the winner.
The forced bet placed by the player immediately to the left of the dealer.
To play a strong hand passively, typically to induce opponents to bet more.
A hand consisting of five sequentially ranked cards, regardless of suit.
A voluntary blind bet made before the cards are dealt, typically twice the big blind.
A mental state where a player becomes frustrated or emotional, leading to poor decision-making.
A pair made with the highest card on the board.
A hand containing three cards of the same rank.
A playing style characterized by playing only strong hands and folding the rest.
The player who is first to act in a round of betting.
A pocket pair lower than the highest card on the board.
A bet made with a hand that is likely to be the best, with the goal of getting called by worse hands.
The opponent in the hand being discussed.
A straight consisting of A-2-3-4-5, the lowest possible straight.
A player with a large bankroll who tends to gamble recklessly.
A term used to refer to a hidden or unknown card, especially when discussing hands during the game.
High denomination chips, typically worth $1,000 in many casinos.
A situation in which a player has no chance of winning the pot, often due to drawing dead.
